data.text: Index
Appendix 1: Primary Care top tips for chronic disease stabilisation prior to referral for surgery
Appendix 2: Protocol for Review of Health Questionnaire
Appendix 3: Administrative process for adding patients to the elective surgery waiting list
Appendix 4: Patients who do not attend an AAU appointment Appendix 5: Preoperative preparation core competencies
Appendix 6: Policy Compliance Monitoring Tool
Appendix 7: Pre-operative preparation pathways by specialty Appendix 8: Enhanced Recovery Programme Procedures
Appendix 9: Preliminary Equality Analysis

The purpose of this policy is to describe the Trust's approach to the preparation of patients prior to having an interventional procedure within the 18 week (RTT) pathway. The policy provides a common framework and a robust process for Trust staff to follow to ensure that patients are prepared appropriately based on the complexity of their procedure and any medical co-morbidity that may pre-exist. This preparation is to be carried out by appropriately trained and competent staff.
This common approach has been designed to meet best practice and standards as set out by the following:
NICE guidance;
Care Quality Commission Outcomes.
That every patient is prepared prior to surgery through a process that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of individuals to ensure:
The patient is in the best medical condition for surgery;
That patients recover more quickly and have a reduced length of stay;
That discharge planning starts prior to admission.

That the level of preparation is based on the complexity of the procedure and the medical fitness of the patient and is carried out to the same high standard with appropriately trained staff to maintain patient safety and quality of care.
That Enhanced Recovery Programme (ERP) is built into the pathway to ensure:
Proactive management of the patient in meeting all enhanced recovery programme compliances;
That all ERP patients have an active role and responsibility for enhancing their recovery.
That a core pathway tailored to specialties will form the basis of this preparation:
To reduce complexity of communication and paperwork;
To reduce duplication in processes and documentation;
To ensure that patient appointments add value to the patients;
That booking processes support this pathway.
That all elements of the pathway will enhance patient experience.

This policy applies to all elective patients over 16 years of age that require a surgical or interventional procedure whether they require a day case or inpatient admission, including patients on the Enhanced Recovery Programme irrespective of the
anaesthetic modality required.
This policy excludes maternity patients where pre-assessment for elective caesarean sections is undertaken by midwives.

The pathway starts at GP referral for patients referred for specific surgical intervention i.e. joint replacement, cataract surgery, hernias. Prior to referral, wherever possible, GP's should ensure that the patient is medically fit for surgery by undertaking some basic diagnostic tests (Appendix 1) to ensure that chronic disease is stabilised before referral. Learning Disability patients must be referred to the Specialist Learning Disability nurse – refer to section 12.

For the majority of other patients the surgical pathway will start in the consultant outpatient clinic when a decision to admit (DTA) for surgery within the 18 week pathway is made. The core pathway is set out in Appendix 3.
At the time of the DTA, a to-come-in (TCI) form will be completed by the admitting
consultant and consent for surgery will be agreed with the patient.

Where appropriate, the patient will be seen by the Specialty Clinical Nurse Specialist to receive further information about the procedure, pathway, discharge planning and how the patient can help to optimise their own recovery. This includes the pre-operative,
intra operative and post-operative information for all ERP patients.
Dependent on the specialty pathways, patients will receive a health questionnaire to
complete in the outpatient clinic when DTA is made. The patient will complete the HQ
on-site. A pre-assessment nurse review of the completed questionnaire will triage the patient to the most appropriate pre-assessment modality.
Nurse-led or Consultant-led preparation (Appendix 2). One of these outcomes will be actioned:
The patient is having a general anaesthetic and requires nurse-led pre-operative preparation (either face-to-face or telephone);
The patient requires Consultant Anaesthetist pre-operative preparation;
Consultant Anaesthetist and cardiopulmonary exercise test (CPET);
Patients with Learning Disabilities may be listed for a GA even when clinically not indicated according to Trust policy.
The patient will be seen within 4 weeks of receiving the AAU request from waiting list in line with the agreed pathway to enable ‘reasonable offers' of appointments to be made.

During the PrOP (pre-operative assessment) or when diagnostic results are known, appropriate actions will be taken based on the medical condition of the patient. On receipt of the results of these tests, further actions will be taken based on the results. When the patient requires no further diagnostics, the PrOP outcome form will be completed and forwarded to the specialty booking clerk for the patient to be considered for an appropriate TCI date.

Nurse-led pre-operative preparation will usually precede consultant anaesthetic assessment but patients for major surgery may be referred directly to the Consultant Anaesthetist clinics. Patients seen by consultant anaesthetists will then be seen in nurse-led preparation and MRSA swabs will be taken in-line with Trust policy.
MRSA / MSSA screening
The guidance set out in the Trust Policy on MRSA screening should be followed. When screening is undertaken it is valid for 13 weeks
Referral to a Consultant Anaesthetist
Consultant Anaesthetic assessment will be undertaken following either a referral from the Surgeon, the Nurse-led PrOP service or the GP. This assessment may take the form of:
Review of diagnostic test results with advice
Review of health records with advice
Consultant appointment with the patient for detailed assessment and further investigations as indicated.
Where a referral is made from the nurse-led service, the patient should be discussed with the Anaesthetist prior to referral.
Where it is known that an anaesthetic assessment will be required as a result of medical co-morbidities that exist, a referral may be made directly to the Consultant Anaesthetist.
Referral back to the GP

A patient can only be deemed not fit enough for surgery after a Consultant Anaesthetist opinion. The Consultant Anaesthetist will write to the Consultant Surgeon and the GP explaining this decision, with a copy to the patient.
Second sides

When a patient is selected for booking for their second side e.g. hip or knee replacement, cataract surgery, the booking clerk should contact the appropriate PrOP service to clarify whether the patient will need a further PrOP appointment. The need for PrOP will take into account, MRSA risk, blood testing and any change in the patient's medical fitness.
Satellite Patients

Nearly every specialty has patients being referred for surgery at the Broomfield site from a clinic on another MEHT site or from a separate Hospital Trust as part of the hub and spoke networks across Essex.

St Peter's, Maldon: These patients will have a TCI card completed and the patient will complete a Health Questionnaire in the OP Clinic. The TCI card and HQ will be forwarded to the booking clerks on the Broomfield site

Braintree Community Hospital: All hip and Knee patients will complete the HQ in the OP clinic. (Patients who fail to meet the requirements of the Braintree PrOP HQ will have their last clinic letter, MRSA outcome and referral forwarded to the Interprovider office at Broomfield Hospital.)

Basildon: When a decision to admit is made in the OP clinic for ENT and Oral Surgery, and it is recognised that the patient requires an overnight stay for surgery, the patient will be given the Health Questionnaire to complete and this will be sent to the booking clerks with the TCI card. For patients that fail PrOP at Basildon for day surgery, a summary of the assessment will be sent with the TCI card to the booking clerk at Broomfield.
Southend (part of Mid and South Essex)
Booking Processes
The Trust Access Policy has been revised to support this pathway. Until patients are returned as ‘green' on their PrOP form they should not be considered for TCI.
Patients who Do Not Attend (DNA)
Patients who DNA their Pre-operative assessment date, having been made a
reasonable offer will be referred back to their referring Consultant (Appendix 4).
Anaesthetic Lead
A Lead Anaesthetist will provide medical leadership for this service. A Senior Nurse for Pre-operative Preparation will provide Trust wide leadership to the nursing staff
undertaking Nurse-led Pre-operative preparation.
Training Requirements

Skills and competencies. The competencies required by nursing staff to undertake PrOP are set out in a separate document (Appendix 5). Each competency is linked to the training requirements for Pre-operative assessment; these will be completed by the staff undertaking pre-operative preparation in each Pre-operative preparation clinic situated in AAU, Gynae OPD, Orthopaedic OPD and St. Andrews OPD.
Staffing Responsibilities
Consultant Led Pre-operative Assessment

A Consultant Anaesthetist will be available within each speciality for advice and to assess patients and they are to ensure that the policy is adhered to for all patients who require elective surgery.
Nurse-led pre-operative preparation

This service has been resourced on the basis of each full time nurse seeing 1440 patients per year. Where possible, the nursing staff will be based in specialty outpatient clinics, working as part of the specialty teams. However, due to facility constraints, nurse-led PrOP for general surgery, urology, ENT and oral surgery is undertaken by the team based on the Anaesthetic Assessment Unit. This unit operates specialty based clinic sessions so that improved communication with the specialties can be developed.
Documentation
Documentation has been developed to support the patient pathway through pre- operative preparation and on to surgery:
Cataract Pre-operative and Operative Record;
Day case general anaesthetic Pre-operative and Operative Record;
Inpatient general anaesthetic Pre-operative and Operative Record including Enhanced Recovery.
Health Questionnaire
Patients will complete a Pre-Surgery Health Questionnaire in the outpatient clinic when a DTA is made.
The ‘Pre-operative and operative record'

Theatreman will be used for recording all Nurse-led and Consultant Anaesthetist pre- operative preparation processes for all patients The Theatreman record will be printed and included within the ‘Pre-operative and Operation Record'.
Pre-operative and operative record booklets have developed for:
Day case general anaesthetic (up to 23 hour stay);
Inpatients.
The LA and DC booklets are stand alone. The Inpatient booklet should be used in conjunction with the ward booklet.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair and meets the needs of all individuals
(Refer to Appendix 9).
Learning Disability
(Refer to 09116 Caring for Adult Patients with a Learning Disability in the Acute Hospital)

The Specialist nurse for Learning Disabilities and Autism must be notified when any patients with Learning Disabilities are scheduled for surgery, the PrOP nurse will notify the waiting list booking clerks of any special requirements on admission e.g. early appointment required to allay unnecessary trauma to the patient.
Patients with a Learning Disability who are unable to demonstrate valid consent must be considered for a GA procedure even when clinically not indicated, in accordance with Trust policy.
Dementia Patients

All patients with Dementia must have a care plan that reflects their individual requirements, in accordance with the Care of patients with dementia policy; register number 10081. Where possible, the patients will be seen with a relative present who will need to accompany the patient on the day of surgery to obtain ascent.
Dialysis Patients
Patients that are receiving dialysis will have their dialysis before surgery, at an
appropriate time, the renal nurses will take pre-operative bloods after the last dialysis before surgery, the patient will be given their blood request forms at the PrOP
assessment and the renal nurses will complete an up to date MRSA screen. The
patients that are receiving dialysis will require a post-operative general anaesthetic
potassium check on the day of surgery. This is to be arranged and checked by the
parent speciality team.

Any breaches of this policy that results in the patients surgery being cancelled on the day for example, incorrect or omission of pre-operative tests, incorrect or admission of information being given to the patient regarding medication, starvation times, length of stay, a Datix must be completed for investigation by a senior nurse.
Complaints and outcome of breaches to be discussed at senior pre-operative preparation nurse meetings, and will identify lessons to be learnt and consideration if an update of the policy is required.
Implementation and Communication

The policy will be made available on the Trust intranet and notification in the staff newsletter, also the senior nurses in each pre-operative preparation clinic will plan training sessions for their staff to implement the updated policy.
References
Royal College of Nursing, 2013. Perioperative fasting in adults and children: an RCN guideline for the multidisciplinary team. London:RCN

Joint British Diabetes Societies for inaptient Care, 2016. Management of adults with diabetes undergoing surgery and elective procedures: improving standards.Revised edition Available at: https://www.diabetes.org.uk/professionals/position-statements-reports/specialist-care- for-children-and-adults-and-complications/management-of-adults-with-diabetes- undergoing-surgery-and-elective-procedures-improving-standards
National Institute for Health and Care excellence (2016). Routine preoperative tests for elective surgery (NG45). London:NICE. Available at: https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/NG45
Appendix 1

table_items.text: Primary Care Top Tips for Chronic Disease Stabilisation

Is the patient aware that they may be listed for surgery? Does the patient want to have surgery? Is the patient likely to benefit from surgery? Is the patient aware of options other than surgery? It may be helpful to offer the patient the use of a decision aid to assist in their decision, these can be found on the following link: Pre op decision tools

Poorly-controlled BP has perioperative cardiac instability / cardiovascular complications. ‘Cosmetic' control of pre-op hypertension is not recommended as vascular auto regulation remains abnormal for up to 6 weeks – ensure stable prior to referral. For patients with ‘White Coat Hypertension' including 3 stable home readings in the referral letter is helpful.
Glycaemic control should be optimized before referral. Hb A1 C of ≤ 70nmol /ml (8.5%) within 3 months of surgery with emphasis on

diet and treatment compliance. Good control can reduce perioperative mortality by 50%.Optimal management of complications of diabetes e.g. renal impairment, cardiac disease, diabetic feet and other infections.

Pre-operative anaemia and blood transfusion are independently associated with adverse outcomes. This is of particular significance prior to joint replacement (major elective surgery) in which a significant risk i.e. transfusion, can be reduced.
Ischaemic Heart Disease, Heart Failure and Cardiomyopathy
Ensure patients' symptoms have been stable with no recent deterioration. Optimize treatment to achieve maximum exercise tolerance. Refer to Cardiologist if required.
Ensure rate control to <100 per minute. Adequate anticoagulation if indicated. (Symptomatic palpitations need investigating)
Clinically euthyroid with TFTs within normal range, checked within previous 6 months. Patient should be on stable treatment dose > 1 month prior to referral.
Aim for symptom control achieving patient's max PEFR and Exercise Tolerance and minimum requirement of prn bronchodilator. Regular bronchodilators or steroid inhalers may be required.

OSA is of a particular concern in anaesthesia due to its increased associated peri- operative morbidity and mortality. It is generally under diagnosed in the community, and is strongly associated with obesity. It is found in 40% of obese women and 50% of obese men. Society of Bariatric anaesthetists score consider the STOP BANG questionnaire before referral for surgery STOP BANG In the event of a referral being made where it has not been possible to stabilise the patient the referral letter should include detailed information about prior management. Consider referral to a physician if further advice is required.

Appendix 5
PRE-OPERATIVE
PREPARATION
CORE COMPETENCIES
Aims of Competency programme
To have the ability to perform clinical examination of the Respiratory systems
To have the ability to conduct a neck and airway assessment
To have the ability to order and perform a 12 lead ECG and identify normal and variant rhythms
To have the ability to order blood tests and perform Venopuncture
To have the ability to obtain accurate history and assessment of patients in Pre-operative preparation
To have the ability to obtain an accurate social history and be able to initiate discharge planning with both the patient and relatives/carers
To have the ability to assess current pain levels, discuss assessment of pain and options for pain management

The pre-operative preparation nurse will have the ability to educate the patient about their surgery, anaesthesia, recovery post operatively, length of stay, fasting times and any other appropriate information leaflets.

The pre-operative preparation nurse will be able to identify the necessity to refer to members of the multi-disciplinary team members, where required, in order to optimise the patient fitness for surgery
The pre-operative preparation nurse will have the ability to review test results and refer to anaesthetist where necessary

The pre-operative preparation nurse will have effective communication skills to enable links with other departments after assessment e.g. Consultants, Clinical Nurse Specialists, secretaries, booking clerks and admitting wards
The pre-operative preparation nurse will have the ability to use Theatreman correctly and accurately, to complete all other documentation fully and neatly
The pre-operative preparation nurse will also take responsibility to update their knowledge and be able to educate and communicate with other colleagues
On completion of the clinical skill competencies the pre-operative preparation nurse will be able to perform a holistic Pre-Operative Assessment.

Please ensure that the documentation is signed and dated, and the pre-operative preparation nurse gains as much experience as possible in order to be proficient in a particular skill, enabling education of their colleagues
CARDIOVASCULAR EXAMINATION AND ASSESSMENT BY A REGISTERED PRACTITIONER

table_items.text: Observed another clinician performing the examination
Performed the examination under direct supervision
Observed performing the examination by a mentor
Describe correct procedure for listening to heart sounds
Describe correct placement of the stethoscope
Describe and identify normal heart sounds
Describe and identify abnormal heart sounds that might be heard
Demonstrate ability to make appropriate referrals for further investigations as required after discussion with an Anaesthetist
Demonstrate accurate documentation recording of findings and any action taken

data.text: ECG RECORDING & BASIC RHYTHM RECOGNITION AND ASSESSMENT BY A REGISTERED PRACTITIONER

table_items.text: Observed another clinician performing the procedure
Performed the procedure under direct supervision
Observed performing the procedure by a mentor
Indicate when a 12 lead ECG may be required and perform one competently
Describe the normal identifiable waveform on an ECG tracing
Accurately document the findings of the ECG and any actions taken

data.text: RESPIRATORY EXAMINATION AND ASSESSMENT BY A REGISTERED PRACTITIONER

table_items.text: Observed another clinician performing the examination
Performed the examination under direct supervision
Observed performing the examination by a mentor
Demonstrates inspection of general patient appearance: skin, nails, nutritional state and use of accessory muscles
Demonstrate accurate recording of respiratory illness
Demonstrate assessment of respiratory rate and pattern
Describe and identify normal breath sounds
Describe and identify abnormal breath sounds
Demonstrate ability to make appropriate referrals for further investigations as required after discussion with an Anaesthetist
Demonstrate accurate documentation recording of listening to breath sounds

data.text: NECK AND AIRWAY EXAMINATION AND ASSESSMENT BY A REGISTERED PRACTITIONER

table_items.text: Observed another clinician performing the procedure
Performed the procedure under direct supervision
Observed performing the procedure by a mentor
Describe the assessment of the airway giving rationale
Describe the assessment of the neck giving rationale
Demonstrate inspection of neck and facial features to recognise potential problems (e.g. Downs syndrome, short fat neck)
Demonstrate ability to assess patient dental history
Accurately document the findings of the neck and airway assessment and document any action taken

data.text: VENOPUNCUTRE ASSESSMENT BY A REGISTERED PRACTITIONER

table_items.text: Observed another clinician performing the procedure
Perform the procedure under direct supervision
Observed performing the procedure by a mentor
Demonstrate ability to order blood tests and give rationale
Demonstrate ability in basic blood result interpretation
Identify abnormal blood results and the ability to make appropriate referrals after discussion with the anaesthetist
Attend the trust Cannulation and Venopuncture study day

data.text: HISTORY AND SOCIAL HISTORY ASSESSMENT BY A REGISTERED PRACTITIONER

table_items.text: Demonstrate ability to use Theatreman record completing a complete accurate past medical history
Demonstrate ability to record a complete social history and initiate discharge planning with relatives, carers and discharge planning team (e.g. EAT, Reablement)
Identify the necessity to refer to members of the multi-disciplinary team (e.g. SALT, dietician, pain management)
Identify the necessity to communicate post assessment outcomes with Consultants, CNS's, secretaries, booking clerks & admitting wards.

Demonstrate ability to educate patients, relatives and carers about their surgery, anaesthesia, medication administration on day of surgery, length of stay, post operative recovery, fasting times and distribute information leaflets
